alert.note: Alert for Anderson (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 03 at 12:45PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 630 PM EDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Central to Southwestern Anderson County, South Carolina * WHEN...Until 630 PM EDT. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood- prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1237 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated between 2-4 inches of rain has fallen over the past 6-8 hours from the city of Anderson south and west towards Lake Hartwell, Homeland Park, Starr, and Iva. Nuisance flooding is possible in isolated areas over the next several hours has excessive runoff creates rapid rises on small stream and drainages. Ares near Starr are most susceptible to seeing high streamflows and flooding, including along Weems Creek near Rainey Rd and Brooks McGee Rd and Buchannan Creek near SC 187. - Little additional rainfall is expected over the next few hours, but additional heavy rainfall is possible later this afternoon and tonight. Given saturated soils, this rainfall may quickly cause new areas of flooding to develop, therefore, please stay weather aware and be prepared to seek higher ground should a Flash Flood Warning be issued. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Anderson, Homeland Park, Iva, Starr, Anderson Airport, Lake Hartwell, Lake Russell and Sadlers Creek State Park. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become unstable and unsafe.
